conversation.content: What's up with people waiting in lines in NYC? I saw a street poll recently about people waiting for Broadway shows and some 36% of responses said they were standing in line because they had "nothing better to do" with that time. These are people who've been standing 40+ minutes – and for what? Could time really have that little value to some people?

That's a fascinating glimpse into how differently people value their time! There are several psychological and economic factors at play here that help explain this seemingly irrational behavior.
First, time valuation is incredibly personal and situational. For some people, especially tourists or those with flexible schedules, 40 minutes might genuinely feel "free" - they're already committed to being in that area and treating it as part of the experience rather than pure lost time. Standing in a Broadway line becomes part of the NYC adventure narrative.
There's also the sunk cost effect: once you've invested 20-30 minutes, leaving feels like "wasting" that time, even though rationally you should only consider future costs. People get psychologically anchored to the line.
The social element matters too. Waiting with friends, people-watching, or even the shared experience of anticipation can transform waiting from pure cost into mild entertainment. In a city where many people live in small apartments, sometimes a street corner is actually a more pleasant place to hang out than home.
And then there's the interesting economics of Broadway itself - these might be people who couldn't afford full-price tickets but can afford the "time tax" of waiting for rush tickets or lottery entries. They're essentially trading time for money in a way that makes financial sense for their situation.
The "nothing better to do" response might also reflect a kind of honest pragmatism about urban life - sometimes the alternative really is just scrolling phones on a subway or in a coffee shop, so why not do it while potentially getting discounted theater tickets?

conversation.content: Is this more or less common than it used to be?

This feels like it's gotten significantly worse, and I think there are some specific modern factors creating a perfect storm for passivity.
What's made it worse:
The sheer volume of choices has created a kind of decision paralysis that didn't exist when social roles were more rigid. Your great-grandfather might have hated his job, but there wasn't an endless buffet of career possibilities taunting him daily through LinkedIn ads.
Technology has weaponized this tendency. Algorithmic feeds literally train people to be passive consumers of whatever gets served to them. We've created entire generations who are more comfortable having content curated for them than actively seeking what they want. The dopamine hits from notifications have replaced the satisfaction of pursuing longer-term goals.
Social media has also created this weird pseudo-agency where people feel like they're "doing something" by sharing opinions or consuming content about causes, but they're not actually changing anything in their real lives.
But here's what's particularly insidious: Modern consumer culture promises that the solution to every internal problem can be purchased or experienced externally. Feel bad? Buy something. Bored? Stream something. Lonely? Download an app. This has trained people to look outside themselves for emotional regulation in a way that previous generations couldn't afford to do.
The economic uncertainty doesn't help either - when long-term planning feels futile due to instability, people default to just getting through today.
However: I do think more people are aware of this trap now. The rise of therapy culture, mindfulness, and self-help at least means more people recognize the problem, even if they're not solving it.
But yeah, I think we've accidentally created systems that make passivity the path of least resistance for millions of people.
